So you think you’re an entrepreneur? Try the Elon Musk test

  • Report this article
Santiago Iniguez

Santiago Iniguez

President, IE University: Reinventing Higher Education 欧阳圣德

Published Sep 30, 2023
+ Follow

Arguably the outstanding business phenomenon of our time, Elon Musk is for many, the epitome of an entrepreneur. An icon for innovators and disruptors and with a huge fan base, particularly among millennials, he is also loathed by many as an unscrupulous opportunist; but then hasn’t business always been about seizing opportunities?

A new biography of Musk by Walter Isaacson, the author of 2011’s Steve Jobs, describes in voluminous detail his childhood, youth and education, his entrepreneurial initiatives, his political concerns, and also his personal relationships—he is the father of 10 children. Good biographies give meaning and consistency to the lives they cover, which are generally contradictory and messy.

 

A serial entrepreneur if ever there was one, Musk co-founded X.com, a pioneering online bank that merged with Confinity, an online payments platform, subsequently morphing into Paypal. This was the origin of Musk’s first fortune, which was reinvested in further projects, notably, Space-X, a leader in the spacecraft and rocket launch industry, and is the largest commercial satellite constellation operator in the world, currently providing support to Ukraine. The company has broken numerous records and surpassed the achievements of NASA. Space X has already sent humans into orbit, reusing or reflighting crewed space capsules, a remarkable achievement based on ever-greater economies of scale.

 

In 2003 Musk founded Tesla, now the most valuable automotive company, and the leading global manufacturer of electric vehicles, and that also produces battery energy storage, solar panels and solar shingles. 

 

A long-standing presence on social networks and rarely out of the headlines, in 2022 he fulfilled one of his dreams by acquiring Twitter, renaming it “X”, with the aim of transforming the platform.

 

This article aims to identify some of the common features of entrepreneurs, using the examples of Elon Musk providing a benchmark for readers to assess their entrepreneurial potential.

What does Elon Musk have in common with Richard Branson, founder of the companies comprising the Virgin Group, Steve Jobs, co-founder of Apple, and Peter Diamandis, who set up the Zero Gravity Corporation? They all started businesses around the age of 20, and that they are now the heads of global corporations active in a range of areas.

 

What’s more, they all had difficult childhoods that may well have contributed to their willingness to take risks and ability to overcome challenges. Branson was dyslexic, and on one occasion, says his mother left him in his pram three miles from home so that he would have to find a way to communicate with strangers if he wanted to get back. At age eight, Diamandis built rockets in his back garden and gave his family and friends lectures about space exploration.

 

Musk was diagnosed with Asperger’s Syndrome, a form of autism-spectrum disorder, which made social relationships challenging: he always understood what people said in a literal sense, but not what they meant. He was an avid reader, didn’t like sports, was bullied at school and treated harshly by his father, being forced to attend lengthy reading sessions during which he couldn’t speak or move. His first wife, Justine Wilson, has said that these adversities helped him “to tune out fear” and made him less risk-averse than others.

 

His fascination with space comes from his love of science fiction novels, particularly Isaac Asimov’s works and Douglas Adams’ The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy. Aged 13, and already addicted to video games, he created Blastar. At the age of 17 he decided to escape the claustrophobic confines of Pretoria, where he had grown up, heading for Canada and making a new life for himself there.

 

Entrepreneurs also share a vision of the future, which is long term, anticipatory, and one in which they see themselves changing the world. Musk insists he is in business to make the world a better place. At university, he wrote a paper entitled "The Importance of Being Solar", which received a high grade. Musk was also part of Donald Trump’s advisory council. However, he left the position after the president pulled the United States out of the Paris climate deal. As a brand ambassador for renewable energy and EVs, Musk felt he had no choice. Looking further afield, Musk wants to  colonize Mars as soon as possible; he says he wants to be buried there.

 

Typically, entrepreneurs demand the impossible to the extent of distorting reality. Bud Tribble, Apple’s chief software engineer, described how Jobs would create a “reality distortion field,” a term taken from Star Trek: “In his presence, reality is malleable. He can convince anyone of practically anything. It wears off when he is not around, but it makes it hard to have realistic schedules.” Jobs’ intransigence was about achieving a very simple goal: to get his people to produce the best possible product; sometimes that meant meeting deadlines that seemed impossible, or checking and rechecking information and data in pursuit of perfection.

 

In similar vein, Isaacson refers to Musk’s “reality-bending willfulness”, which generates pressure on those responsible to achieve objectives. For example, on one occasion Tom Mueller, head of engines for the Space X’s Merlin rockets, complained at a request to reduce the production’s lead time by half for the second time. Musk then asked him if he wanted to continue heading his unit. After responding in the affirmative, Musk told him:  “Fuck, when I ask for something, you give it to me!”

 

Entrepreneurs share a similar approach to strategy, focusing more on their projects, products and services than on the financial aspects of their businesses. This is the difference between an entrepreneur, somebody who has a deep personal stake in their projects, and a manager, who is more concerned with meeting deadlines, evaluating contingencies, and handling resources. “I don’t complicate my life with financial reports,” Branson once famously said, admitting he didn’t know the difference between net and gross profit.

 

It's been said that Musk isn’t motivated by money, and instead by implanting ideas though a strategic mindset that has been partly molded by practicing strategy videogames like The Battle of Polytopia or Civilization. Isaacson notes that the family’s motto was “Live dangerously – carefully”. Arguably more apt would be the maxim quoted by Musk’s cousin Peter: “Risk is a type of fuel”.

 

That said, Musk has never ignored the financials. A consistent practice undertaken by Musk, and key to the success of Space-X, has been to question all costs, something that also led him to decide to manufacture practically all the components involved in the construction of his rockets. He asked his engineers to question all specifications, and approach that would later become the first step of a checklist dubbed “the algorithm,” that would become his oft-reiterated mantra in product development.

 

A member of his team recalls an incident that illustrates Musk’s approach: a group of engineers responded to a question on the design of rocket components saying: “There is a military specification that says this is a requirement.” To which Musk replied: “Who wrote that? What's the point?"

 

The team then understood that all formal requirements were merely recommendations. The only immutable ones were those decreed by the laws of physics. This was a major advance to shifting the lead time.

 

Another characteristic of entrepreneurs is their restlessness, their determination, and even their obsession with getting a project off the ground. They are perfectionists and have a seemingly boundless capacity for work. Branson’s passion for aviation and space travel led him to sell Virgin Records, the label he set up with three friends in 1972 at the age of 22, and which had made his fortune, in order to keep Virgin Atlantic in the air at a time when it faced unfair competition from British Airways, along with soaring fuel costs.

 

Musk, who reportedly works a 100-hour week, spent most of his fortune on SpaceX, Tesla, and then Twitter, all decisions considered at best risky—and by some of questionable sanity. He confided to Isaacson that he has been in “crisis mode” for the last 15 years. As a child, fearing being punished by his mother, he climbed a tree and refused to come down. His brother Kimbal says he never ceases to be “astonished”  by Musk’s determination. Isaacson portrays Musk as having the character of a street fighter, combative, but also able to accept defeat: he has a “maniac sense of urgency”.

While sure of their abilities , entrepreneurs of this caliber are also aware of their limitations, which is why they typically surround themselves with the best professionals and highly qualified teams, of whom they then demand the impossible on top of the impossible. Branson hired Burt Rutan, one of the most respected aircraft and rocket designers in the world, to create SpaceShipOne, the first privately funded manned spacecraft, which carried out its first flight in 2004. Musk too knows how to pick the best and to motivate them to perform beyond the normal.

 

As regards Musk, the following quote is revealing: "If you were negative or thought something couldn't be done, you weren't invited to the next meeting", Mueller recalls. "He just wanted people willing to make things happen." And it seems that was a good way to push people to do what they thought was impossible.

According to Chris Impey, though there is no evidence in support of this, they may also share the 7R variant of the DRD4 gene, carried by a fifth of humanity and that controls dopamine, the chemical associated with risk-takers, extroverts, and explorers. The gene variant is believed to have emerged around 40,000 years ago, around the time our forebears began migrating out of Africa, and has been identified in their descendants in far-flung places. For Impey, the will to explore is “built into our DNA,” meaning we will establish a presence in space, sooner or later. However, expert geneticist Professor Kenneth Kidd of Yale University plays down the role of genetics in behavior, noting: “You just can’t reduce something as complex as human exploration to a single gene. Genetics doesn’t work that way.”

 

More than one commentator has drawn parallels between Musk and the Übermenschen created by Ayn Rand in her series of novels written in the 1950s, such as John Galt, the protagonist of Atlas Shrugged. In a lengthy speech, Galt explains that US society is divided into two main groups: the doers, composed of the business class, and the non-doers, who are the representatives of government and religion. The figure of Atlas represents the former, who carry the weight of the world on their shoulders, creating wealth and transforming society. According to one commentator, Atlas Shrugged was written “to show how desperately the world needs prime movers and how viciously it treats them and to portray what happens to the world without them. All along the book, there is the ongoing distinction between the ‘true’ entrepreneurs, who seek to make profits purely by their own innovative efforts, and the false ones who benefit from government patronage and are counted among the looters”.

 

Finally, do entrepreneurs ever find time to rest or to escape the myriad pressures they have created for themselves? Richard Branson has his own Caribbean island where he gets away from it all. Isaacson says that Musk relaxes by playing video games, reading—especially science fiction—and parties, which apparently can go on for some time, although he always remains in control, sober, presumably his next venture never far from his thoughts. We wait with baited breath.

Elon Musk: the man, the myth, the Iron Man of the business world. He's like the superhero we can't decide if we love or loathe. On one hand, he's out there trying to save the planet and colonize Mars, but on the other, he's renaming Twitter like it's his own social media playground. One thing's for sure, if you're not playing 4D chess on your way to world domination, are you even an entrepreneur these days? Musk and his fellow visionaries remind us that sometimes you've got to be a little bit crazy to change the world, and a touch of gaming and a Caribbean island don't hurt either.

Really resonated with these strong telltales of a real entrepreneur. If possessed, must be embodied. No choice there for the person, like cordyceps compelling an ant to reach the highest leaf. Difficult childhoods are (tragic but) such an edge once overcome. Depending on brain chemistry, there is a higher chance to "level up" with a low tolerance for being passive and appeasing in the face of big problems. Sure, they may behave "strange" and not fit a mold, but they are the ones embracing uncertainty and getting their hands dirty. I picture the frontier homo sapiens readying to get out of Africa (to an equivalent tune of The Times They Are A-Changin'), with naysayers sitting on their high boulders not doing a thing.
